Author: CrisF#3405
Content: Ahh, a bit quieter here.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
Incentivized testing is only a feature of what KMDLabs offers. And the PoC for that proved it works very well.
Projects needing specific plans for incentivized tests can set them up with us. There is a risk of 'loosing' money, but testing software generally isn't free at that level anyhow.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: Of course there is also the possibility of gain too.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Its a lot about keeping devs making stuff together as well, colabaration, as they all share the same coin, rather than having a new token for evey contract, this allows things to happen much faster than usual, as have already been proven by what we have done already.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
Also the people using the test cluster aren't and probably won't only be devs looking to profit. Of course there is that possibility. 
Many of the people now are there to learn through there testing.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
As for the testers, not all and probably not most are there for a salary or even a big score.  I was there to learn, help and maybe as a very long shot get some valuable coins back.
Many people have projects, ideas, or in some cases just dreams, that they need a place to work on. KMDLabs gives them that place. The ease of use and network of support makes that very much easier than doing by themselves.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
Yeah LABS has saves time.  Everything you do saves the newbie blockchain  üêí  operator from starting from zero.  Just like Ubuntu took Debian‚Äôs testing repo and accelerated the Debian release process.  Check history from Debian Sid to the following releases.

When a dApp team knows front end coding and some of the crypto conditions logic but not vin/vout details, they‚Äôre not going to know blockchain ops, mining pools, coin migrations etc.

Getting a product to market or productization of an idea needs agility and flexibility.  LABS gives this to the ecosystem.

Author: Seko#7408
Content:
Hello guys...
I'm trying to compare a PoS-based crypto currency with Pirate.

PoS is protected against 51 % attacks.  In addition, PoS could become more interesting in the future for environmentally friendly reasons.  Even Ethereum is working on a hybrid version.  I am asking myself how Komodo wants to solve this problem?  Hybrid with the help of Veruscoin?  Or is it something you don't even think about?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: PoS has some other issues than 51% attack, though dPoW likely solves most of them

Author: Seko#7408
Content: Where are the advantages of dPoW in compare to PoS? And what about the environmental idea?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you cant compare dPoW to PoS

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: dPoW works with whatever existing consensus mechanism

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: weakness of PoS is not external reference

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: dPoW is all about external reference

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you need to at least understand a bit about PoS weakness to understand

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: https://medium.com/@robertgreenfieldiv/vulnerability-proof-of-work-vs-proof-of-stake-f0c44807d18c

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: seems a decent comparison

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: well, i guess it ignores the 51% attack for PoW, i guess it goes without saying

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
If consensus is a layer of concrete on the sidewalk/pavement, and your layer of concrete is as thick as your community invollved (PoW or PoS), there is still one layer of concrete.

One layer of concrete is pretty easy to drill into and make a hole for a person to squeeze into.

dPoW adds 2 more concrete layers (KMD & BTC), and an important timing layer.

Try drilling into 3 layers of concrete, of different grades.  You need different drill bits to go through different harder concrete.

The KMD & BTC layers also have steel mesh to re-inforce and strengthen it.
Your drill needs to be good enough to drill through 3 layers of concrete, be wide enough for the  person to climb into.

The drill holes are filled by very quickly drying cement, almost as soon as someone tries drilling into it - because the cement auto-repairs as time moves forwards (blocks are made).

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: *involved (typo)

Author: Regnar#6164
Content: I think there be a pinned message for this channel to explain what it is all about.

Author: Regnar#6164
Content:
But this seems business related, FDA is testing a permissioned blockchain for healthcare providers to share access to sensitive information. It started with 4 hospitals (not sure where it's at now) but they are using the consulting firm Booz Allen Hamilton to develop a solution. Seems they are using Ethereum but adding privacy features (I believe off-chain)
<https://gcn.com/articles/2018/06/22/fda-blockchain-ehr-sharing.aspx>

Here's Booz Allen Hamilton's white paper in regards to the chain.
<https://blockchainhealthcaretoday.com/index.php/journal/article/view/13/17>

TLDR: Building permissioned blockchain that provides 3 tiers of information access, a descriptor(public), summary (permissioned), and full access (permissioned). They said "special purpose software designed to work along side the blockchain must be implemented to facilitate additional layers of encryption that enforce the privacy of content embedded within transaction data"
Also that "the data owner may revoke access to a piece of shared data with a guarantee that even a receiver‚Äôs private key together with the raw blockchain transaction data would not be sufficient to obtain data access"

@Steve Lee and @Bitcoin Benny, thoughts on this for a business opportunity/use case for Komodo? Seems the privacy aspect could be something Komodo could do well.

Author: Regnar#6164
Content:
Marek Cyran - Chief Scientist - Booz Allen Hamilton (Author of that white paper)
LinkedIn: <https://www.linkedin.com/in/marek-cyran-82018011/> 
email : Cyran_Marek2@bah.com

Lauren Neal - Principal Strategy Innovations Group - Booz Allen Hamilton (On that project)
LinkedIn: <https://www.linkedin.com/in/laurenberrymanneal/>

We should reach out to these people just to make a connection, talk with them about the types of things they see their clients needing from blockchain and what is missing from projects like Ethereum. What they have to do to get around the limitations they are seeing on chain, and we can attempt to develop solutions, or might even already have the solutions (zk-snarks for privacy, language agnostic for contracts, etc) in order to make Komodo a more attractive platform. And then we can be on their minds when they look to implement another Blockchain for their clients.

Author: cipi#4502
Content:
hmmm, does not matter what i do, i get the error even with empty datadir
```creditsd: chainparams.cpp:175: CMainParams::CMainParams(): Assertion `consensus.hashGenesisBlock == uint256S("0x0000dea5d2c92cf3f1dce5031cc2b368b2a5e3ebea73ea1278fef673d10b1345")' failed.
Aborted```

Author: Cranky#9935
Content: Ok, I thought I have seen this before and I have. Here is a closed task I had in the Credits Discord channel -

Author: Cranky#9935
Content:
```
#19 Resolve an issue with the genesis block hash which is preventing compilation of Credits on some systems.

creditsd: chainparams.cpp:173: CMainParams::CMainParams(): Assertion `consensus.hashGenesisBlock == uint256S("0x0000dea5d2c92cf3f1dce5031cc2b368b2a5e3ebea73ea1278fef673d10b1345")'
failed.
Only single user (BarterDEX reporting this issue. Suspect previous blockchain data present). Bounty removed.
Closing. BarterDEX have confirmed it as a non-issue. They were using a replacement library for malloc (faster, more efficient) and that seemed to cause the problem
```

Author: cipi#4502
Content: thanks, it works now... updated my build instructions to exclude malloc-replacement for CRDS

Author: Cranky#9935
Content: Thanks @cipi I‚Äôll make a note for future releases

Content: Hi Komodo, I  am not sure if this is a BD or a marketing support question so I will post here.

Content: We are running a crypto -> giftcard platform, and have users asking for Komodo integration. We considering doing the integration but are wondering if we could get additional support.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: Im sure we will hear it from customers,   gift cards tend to be a hot market.   Cant promote something noone has first hand experience with.   Do the integration, post about it on Reddit,  people will try it out, if its good,  word will spread other places

Content: I understand sapling addresses are pretty efficient and removing z-addressing might be the proper way to move forward swiftly.
